title: CFP Ethics and Professional Responsibility (CFP Board)
description: Applies the CFP Board Code of Ethics and Standards of Conduct to common adviser scenarios: fiduciary duty, conflicts, disclosure, confidentiality, and professional judgment.

questions.question: Under the CFP Board Code of Ethics and Standards of Conduct, when does the CFP professional's fiduciary duty apply?
options: Only when providing investment advice for a fee (not commission)
Only when signing an investment policy statement (IPS)
When providing Financial Advice to a Client
Only when managing discretionary portfolios
questions.explanation: The Standards impose a fiduciary duty when a CFP professional provides Financial Advice to a Client, not only in fee-only or discretionary contexts.

questions.question: Scenario: You will receive a referral fee if your client uses a particular mortgage broker. What is the most appropriate next step under the Standards?
options: Proceed without disclosure if the fee is small
Disclose the referral arrangement and the material conflict, and obtain the client's informed consent before proceeding
Disclose only after the client closes the mortgage
Avoid documentation to reduce liability
questions.explanation: Referral compensation creates a material conflict. You must disclose it and obtain informed consent before providing advice or a recommendation tied to that conflict.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best example of a *material* conflict of interest that must be disclosed?
options: You prefer morning meetings to afternoon meetings
You receive third-party compensation that varies depending on the product selected
You use a standardized planning template across clients
You work from home two days per week
questions.explanation: Variable third-party compensation can reasonably be expected to affect your advice and is a material conflict requiring disclosure and management.

questions.question: Scenario: A client insists on implementing a strategy you believe is not in their best interest. What is the best course of action consistent with the Standards?
options: Implement immediately without further discussion because the client requested it
Refuse to discuss alternatives to avoid appearing confrontational
Explain the risks and why you do not recommend it, offer alternatives, and document the client's informed decision if they still proceed
Suggest they keep it secret from other professionals involved
questions.explanation: You should provide competent advice, try to prevent foreseeable harm, and keep appropriate records. If a client proceeds, document the discussion and rationale.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the difference between the Duty of Loyalty and the Duty of Care?
options: Loyalty is about documentation; Care is about marketing communications
Loyalty is about acting in the client's best interest and managing conflicts; Care is about competence, diligence, and skill in delivering advice
Loyalty only applies to investments; Care only applies to insurance
They are identical; the Standards do not distinguish them
questions.explanation: The Duty of Loyalty centers on putting the client first and managing conflicts; the Duty of Care focuses on competent, diligent, and professional performance.

questions.question: Scenario: You discover an error in a client's plan that could materially affect recommendations. What should you do?
options: Ignore it unless the client notices
Correct the error, promptly inform the client as appropriate, reassess recommendations, and document the remediation
Wait until the next annual review
Delete the working papers to avoid scrutiny
questions.explanation: Competence and diligence require correcting material errors and communicating appropriately; documentation supports accountability and audit readiness.

questions.question: Under the Standards, which is the *best* description of 'informed consent' to a material conflict?
options: The client remains silent after you mention a conflict
The client understands the conflict and its consequences and agrees to proceed
You add the conflict to your website footer
Your supervisor approves the conflict internally
questions.explanation: Informed consent requires the client to understand the material conflict and agree to proceed, not mere silence or internal approval.

questions.question: Which situation is most likely to permit disclosure of confidential client information without the client's consent?
options: A colleague asks out of curiosity
A family member calls claiming urgency
A legal obligation requires disclosure (e.g., a valid court order)
A competitor requests benchmarking data
questions.explanation: Confidentiality is fundamental, but lawful requirements (e.g., valid legal process) can mandate disclosure.

questions.question: Scenario: You recommend a proprietary model portfolio with higher internal fees than comparable alternatives. Which action best aligns with the Standards?
options: Recommend it without disclosure because it is proprietary
Disclose all relevant conflicts and costs, compare reasonable alternatives, and recommend it only if it is in the client's best interest
Recommend it only to high-net-worth clients to reduce complaints
Ask the client to waive their right to ask questions
questions.explanation: Higher fees and proprietary incentives are conflicts/cost considerations. You must disclose, evaluate alternatives, and act in the client's best interest.

questions.question: The CFP Board has approved an increase in continuing education requirements from 30 to 40 hours per two-year cycle. When is this change scheduled to take effect?
options: Immediately (next business day)
January 1, 2026
Quarter 1 of 2027
January 1, 2030
questions.explanation: The CFP Board has announced the increase is scheduled to become effective in Q1 2027.

title: CFP Retirement and Income Planning
description: Retirement income fundamentals: income sources, withdrawal strategy tradeoffs, longevity risk, sequence-of-returns risk, Social Security and pension decision points.

questions.question: Which risk is most directly addressed by purchasing a lifetime income annuity (e.g., SPIA/DIA) as part of a retirement income plan?
options: Inflation risk only
Longevity risk
Currency risk
Credit spread risk only
questions.explanation: Lifetime income annuities are primarily used to pool longevity risk, helping protect against outliving assets.

questions.question: Scenario: A retiree begins withdrawals during a major market drawdown. Which concept best describes the heightened long-term risk to portfolio sustainability?
options: Basis risk
Sequence-of-returns risk
Reinvestment risk
Tracking error
questions.explanation: Negative returns early in retirement can permanently impair sustainability. This is sequence-of-returns risk.

questions.question: Which account is generally NOT subject to required minimum distributions (RMDs) during the original owner's lifetime?
options: Traditional IRA
Roth IRA
SEP IRA
questions.explanation: Roth IRAs are generally exempt from lifetime RMDs for the original owner (rules differ for some employer plans).

questions.question: Scenario: A client is deciding between a single-life pension and a joint-and-survivor pension. What is the key tradeoff to evaluate?
options: Tax filing status changes only
Higher current payment vs. survivor income protection for a spouse/beneficiary
Whether the pension is held in a trust
Whether Social Security will be cancelled
questions.explanation: Joint-and-survivor options typically reduce the current payment to provide continuing income to a survivor.

questions.question: Which statement best reflects the role of a written retirement income policy in a plan?
options: It guarantees returns
It replaces the need for asset allocation
It sets decision rules for spending adjustments, helping manage behavioral and market risks
It is required by IRS for all retirees
questions.explanation: A policy provides structured decision rules (spending adjustments, guardrails), reducing ad hoc reactions in volatile markets.

questions.question: Scenario: A client wants to maximize guaranteed income and is willing to give up liquidity on a portion of assets. Which solution most directly aligns?
options: Short-term CD ladder only
Immediate annuitization of part of the portfolio
100% equity allocation
Day trading
questions.explanation: Immediate annuitization trades liquidity for contractual income, which can stabilize retirement cash flow.

questions.question: Which planning lever can help mitigate inflation risk in retirement (among other tools)?
options: Holding all assets in cash indefinitely
Including assets with inflation sensitivity and reviewing spending assumptions
Avoiding rebalancing
Ignoring cost-of-living changes
questions.explanation: Inflation-sensitive assets and realistic spending assumptions help manage inflation risk; cash alone can lose purchasing power.

questions.question: Scenario: A client is considering claiming Social Security earlier than planned due to anxiety about market volatility. What is the most appropriate adviser response?
options: Tell them Social Security claiming does not affect lifetime benefits
Explain the tradeoffs (reduced monthly benefit vs. early cash flow) and evaluate against longevity and other income sources
Recommend early claiming for all clients
Advise them to ignore Social Security and focus only on investments
questions.explanation: Claiming is a longevity and cash-flow decision. Advisers should quantify tradeoffs and align the choice to goals and risks.

questions.question: Which is a common objective of maintaining a 'cash bucket' in a bucket strategy?
options: To maximize volatility
To fund near-term spending and reduce forced selling of equities in downturns
To avoid taxes entirely
To eliminate the need for insurance
questions.explanation: Cash/short-duration reserves can fund spending during drawdowns, reducing sequence-of-returns damage.

questions.question: Scenario: A retiree's portfolio has appreciated significantly, pushing equities above target allocation. What is the best practice action?
options: Do nothing; drift is always optimal
Rebalance toward the target allocation considering tax and transaction costs
Shift entirely to cash
Increase equity exposure further without limit
questions.explanation: Rebalancing helps keep risk aligned with plan targets while considering taxes and costs.

title: CFP Tax Planning Fundamentals
description: Core U.S. tax-planning concepts used in financial planning: marginal vs effective rate, capital gains, tax-loss harvesting, Roth vs traditional, and common compliance pitfalls.

questions.question: Which statement best distinguishes a marginal tax rate from an effective tax rate?
options: Marginal rate applies to total tax paid; effective rate applies to the next dollar of income
Marginal rate applies to the next dollar of taxable income; effective rate is total tax divided by total income
They are always identical
Effective rate applies only to capital gains
questions.explanation: Marginal rate applies to incremental taxable income; effective rate reflects overall tax burden relative to income.

questions.question: Scenario: A client sells an appreciated security held for more than one year. Which tax treatment is most commonly triggered under U.S. federal rules?
options: Ordinary income treatment
Long-term capital gain treatment
Gift tax treatment
Payroll tax treatment
questions.explanation: Holding periods over one year generally qualify gains for long-term capital gain treatment (subject to exceptions).

questions.question: What is the wash sale rule primarily designed to prevent?
options: Claiming a capital loss while immediately repurchasing a substantially identical security
Paying taxes on dividends
Rebalancing portfolios annually
Contributing to retirement accounts
questions.explanation: A wash sale disallows a loss if the investor purchases a substantially identical security within the wash sale window.

questions.question: Scenario: A client realizes capital gains and is considering tax-loss harvesting. What is a primary benefit of harvesting losses (if done correctly)?
options: It guarantees higher returns
It can offset capital gains and potentially reduce taxable income
It eliminates the need to report trades
It converts capital gains into tax-exempt income
questions.explanation: Tax-loss harvesting can offset gains and, subject to limits, reduce taxable income; it does not guarantee returns.

questions.question: Which statement about a Roth conversion is generally accurate?
options: The converted amount is never taxable
The converted amount is generally included in taxable income for the year of conversion
Conversions are only allowed after age 70 and a half
Conversions eliminate all future tax reporting
questions.explanation: Roth conversions are generally taxable in the year converted; they can be useful for managing future tax and RMD dynamics.

questions.question: Scenario: A client wants to donate to charity and also reduce capital gains. Which approach most directly supports both objectives?
options: Donate appreciated securities held long-term (instead of cash)
Donate only cash from a credit card advance
Donate a security at a loss without considering wash sale rules
Donate a personal-use asset without documentation
questions.explanation: Donating appreciated long-term securities can avoid realizing capital gains while providing a charitable benefit (subject to applicable rules).

questions.question: Which statement best describes tax-exempt municipal bond interest (general concept)?
options: It is always taxable at federal and state levels
It is generally exempt from U.S. federal income tax, with state treatment varying
It is exempt from all taxes globally
It is treated as earned income for retirement contributions
questions.explanation: Municipal interest is generally federal tax-exempt, but state rules vary and some exceptions can apply.

questions.question: Scenario: A client expects to be in a higher tax bracket later and values tax diversification. Which contribution type can support that goal?
options: Traditional pre-tax contributions only
Roth contributions (after-tax) as part of a diversified approach
Avoiding retirement accounts
Only holding cash
questions.explanation: Roth contributions can provide tax-free qualified distributions later and improve tax diversification.

questions.question: Which is a key documentation practice in tax planning that reduces compliance risk?
options: Relying on verbal assumptions without notes
Keeping records of assumptions, sources, and the rationale for recommendations
Deleting draft calculations
Avoiding client emails
questions.explanation: Clear documentation of assumptions and rationale improves defensibility and supports consistent client outcomes.

questions.question: Scenario: A client wants to claim a large deduction but cannot substantiate it. What is the best professional response?
options: Encourage them to claim it anyway
Advise that deductions require proper substantiation and recommend obtaining documentation or consulting a qualified tax professional
Ignore the issue because it is the client's responsibility
Suggest splitting the deduction across multiple years without support
questions.explanation: Professionals should not facilitate unsupported claims; the appropriate response is to require substantiation and refer to qualified tax advice when needed.

title: CFP Investment Management and Fiduciary Duty
description: Portfolio management and adviser duty: IPS design, risk profiling, diversification, rebalancing, cost and conflict evaluation, and best execution principles.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of an Investment Policy Statement (IPS) in a client relationship?
options: To predict market returns
To document objectives, constraints, risk parameters, and the agreed investment process
To replace all regulatory disclosures
To guarantee suitability of any future product
questions.explanation: An IPS is a governance document that clarifies objectives/constraints and the process for managing the portfolio consistently.

questions.question: Scenario: A client says they can tolerate high volatility, but their near-term spending needs and time horizon indicate limited risk capacity. What is the best next step?
options: Ignore risk capacity and invest aggressively
Educate the client on the difference between tolerance and capacity, align recommendations to objectives/constraints, and document the discussion
Refuse to discuss risk and proceed with a standard allocation
Recommend leverage to increase returns quickly
questions.explanation: Good practice incorporates both risk tolerance and capacity; documenting the rationale supports a defensible recommendation.

questions.question: Which is the most accurate description of diversification?
options: Owning many securities always guarantees no losses
Reducing idiosyncratic risk by holding imperfectly correlated assets and avoiding undue concentration
Investing only in one sector to become an expert
Timing the market to buy low and sell high
questions.explanation: Diversification reduces unsystematic risk by spreading exposure; it cannot eliminate market risk.

questions.question: Scenario: You recommend a higher-cost proprietary fund when a comparable lower-cost alternative exists. Which action best supports fiduciary decision-making?
options: Assume proprietary is better because it is in-house
Evaluate costs, performance drivers, and suitability; disclose conflicts; and recommend only if it is in the client's best interest
Hide fee details to avoid confusion
Ask the client to sign a waiver that you are not responsible for fees
questions.explanation: Fiduciary practice requires evaluating reasonable alternatives, disclosing conflicts, and selecting what best meets client needs.

questions.question: What is rebalancing primarily intended to accomplish?
options: Increase returns in all markets
Restore the portfolio to its target risk profile and allocation over time
Avoid all taxable events
Eliminate the need for monitoring
questions.explanation: Rebalancing helps keep risk aligned with targets; it can also enforce discipline but doesn't guarantee returns.

questions.question: Scenario: In a volatile market, a client wants to sell everything after reading alarming headlines. What is the most appropriate adviser response?
options: Execute immediately without discussion
Revisit goals, time horizon, and IPS; explain tradeoffs of panic selling; consider risk-aligned adjustments; and document the rationale
Tell them you are too busy to discuss
Recommend doubling down on the riskiest assets
questions.explanation: Behavioral coaching is part of prudent advice: reconnect actions to objectives and risk parameters and document decisions.

questions.question: Which statement best describes 'best execution' in trade handling?
options: Always using the broker with the lowest commission
Taking reasonable steps to obtain the most favorable terms reasonably available under the circumstances
Executing trades only at market open
Executing only through the adviser's affiliated broker
questions.explanation: Best execution is a process standard considering price, speed, likelihood of execution, and total cost, not just commission.

questions.question: Which cost is most directly reflected in a fund's expense ratio?
options: Broker trade commissions in the client account
Internal fund operating expenses charged at the fund level
The adviser's planning fee
State income tax
questions.explanation: Expense ratios reflect ongoing internal fund expenses; adviser fees and client commissions are separate cost components.

questions.question: Scenario: A client is moving from accumulation to decumulation. Which change is most likely warranted in the investment approach?
options: Increase volatility to maximize excitement
Reassess allocation and liquidity needs to support near-term cash flows and sequence risk management
Remove all fixed income categorically
Stop monitoring the portfolio
questions.explanation: Decumulation increases cash-flow sensitivity; portfolio design often emphasizes liquidity, downside control, and spending sustainability.

questions.question: Which statement best contrasts a suitability standard with a fiduciary standard in practice?
options: Suitability requires acting in the client's best interest; fiduciary only requires disclosure
Suitability focuses on appropriate recommendations; fiduciary generally requires putting client interests first and managing conflicts beyond mere appropriateness
They are identical under all regimes
Fiduciary applies only to insurance
questions.explanation: Fiduciary standards typically add duties of loyalty/care and stronger conflict management beyond basic appropriateness.

title: CFP Estate Planning and Wealth Transfer
description: Estate planning essentials: wills, trusts, beneficiary designations, powers of attorney, probate, and common wealth-transfer planning considerations.

questions.question: Which statement about beneficiary designations is generally correct?
options: A will always overrides beneficiary designations on retirement accounts
Beneficiary designations typically control distribution of the account even if a will says otherwise
Beneficiary designations are irrelevant for insurance policies
Beneficiary designations only matter for taxable accounts
questions.explanation: Beneficiary designations commonly govern transfer of many accounts/policies and can override inconsistent will provisions.

questions.question: Scenario: A client has minor children and significant assets. Which planning tool most directly helps manage and distribute assets for minors?
options: A joint checking account only
A trust arrangement (e.g., testamentary or living trust) with a designated trustee
A credit card account
A verbal instruction to relatives
questions.explanation: Trusts can set terms and appoint a trustee to manage assets for minors until conditions are met.

questions.question: What is a common benefit of a revocable living trust?
options: It eliminates all taxes automatically
It can help avoid probate and provide privacy/continuity in asset management
It is irrevocable once signed
It is only for charitable giving
questions.explanation: Revocable trusts are often used to streamline administration and avoid probate for titled assets properly funded into the trust.

questions.question: Scenario: A client wants to ensure someone can make financial decisions if they become incapacitated. Which document most directly addresses this need?
options: A prenuptial agreement
A durable financial power of attorney
A beneficiary designation
A credit report authorization
questions.explanation: A durable financial power of attorney authorizes an agent to act on financial matters if the principal becomes incapacitated.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the general tax basis concept often associated with inherited appreciated assets?
options: Basis always becomes zero
Basis generally adjusts at death under applicable rules (commonly called a step-up/down in basis)
Basis can never change
Basis becomes the beneficiary's purchase price
questions.explanation: Many inherited assets receive a basis adjustment at death under current rules, impacting future capital gains.

questions.question: Scenario: A client in a blended family wants to provide for a surviving spouse while preserving assets for children from a prior marriage. Which approach is commonly used?
options: Rely only on verbal promises
Use a trust structure that can provide spouse income/benefit with remainder to children
Name only the new spouse as beneficiary of everything
Put all assets in jointly titled accounts with the spouse
questions.explanation: Trust structures can balance spouse support with controlled remainder distribution to children from a prior relationship.

questions.question: Which is a key difference between a will and a trust (general concept)?
options: Wills are private; trusts are public
Wills generally take effect at death and may go through probate; trusts can operate during life and after death if funded
Trusts can only hold real estate; wills cannot
A will replaces the need for beneficiary designations
questions.explanation: Wills commonly require probate and operate at death; funded trusts can manage assets during incapacity and after death.

questions.question: Scenario: A client's estate plan is outdated after a divorce and remarriage. What is the most appropriate professional next step?
options: Do nothing; estate plans never need updating
Prompt a full review of beneficiaries, titling, and documents, and coordinate with qualified estate counsel
Change documents yourself regardless of licensing
Only update the will and ignore account beneficiaries
questions.explanation: Life events can invalidate assumptions. A comprehensive review (including beneficiary designations) and legal coordination is best practice.

questions.question: Which document most directly communicates healthcare wishes and appoints a healthcare decision-maker?
options: Healthcare directive / medical power of attorney
Mortgage note
Brokerage statement
Tax transcript
questions.explanation: Advance healthcare directives and medical powers of attorney guide treatment preferences and designate decision-makers.

questions.question: Scenario: A client wants charitable legacy while still receiving income during their lifetime. Which strategy is commonly used (general concept)?
options: Charitable remainder trust arrangement
Paying all income to heirs immediately
Holding only cash
Avoiding any written plan
questions.explanation: Charitable remainder arrangements can provide lifetime income with a remainder interest to charity (subject to legal/tax rules).

title: FINRA Regulatory Element: Anti-Money Laundering (AML) Essentials
description: AML fundamentals for FINRA-registered persons: AML program elements, red flags, escalation, SAR confidentiality, and practical client scenarios.

questions.question: Under FINRA Rule 3310, which set of elements is required in a broker-dealer's AML compliance program?
options: A marketing plan, social media policy, brand guidelines, and quarterly sales targets
Policies and procedures reasonably designed for AML compliance, independent testing, a designated AML officer, and ongoing training
Only customer identification procedures
Only an annual attestation by the CEO
questions.explanation: FINRA Rule 3310 requires a written AML program with core elements including procedures, independent testing, AML officer designation, and training.

questions.question: Scenario: A customer repeatedly breaks large cash deposits into smaller amounts and asks staff to process them separately. This pattern most strongly suggests:
options: Normal activity with no concern
Structuring to evade reporting/monitoring
A routine payroll process
A dividend reinvestment plan
questions.explanation: Repeatedly splitting transactions to avoid reporting or scrutiny is a classic structuring red flag requiring escalation.

questions.question: Which statement about suspicious activity reporting is most accurate for front-line staff?
options: Staff should tell the client a SAR is being filed to encourage cooperation
Staff should escalate suspicious activity internally following firm procedures; SAR filings are handled through the firm's AML process
SARs are optional when the client is wealthy
SARs can be posted publicly for transparency
questions.explanation: Employees should follow internal escalation protocols. SAR filing is a controlled process and SAR confidentiality rules prohibit tipping off.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a Customer Identification Program (CIP) in an AML context?
options: To select investment products
To verify a customer's identity using risk-based procedures
To optimize tax alpha
To generate marketing leads
questions.explanation: CIP procedures help ensure the firm knows who the customer is, supporting AML and sanctions compliance.

questions.question: Scenario: A client instructs you to wire funds to an unrelated third party in a high-risk jurisdiction and refuses to explain the purpose. What is the best next step?
options: Execute immediately to avoid upsetting the client
Conduct appropriate due diligence, escalate to AML/compliance per policy, and consider whether the activity is suspicious
Ask the client to split the wire into smaller amounts
Ignore it if the client has a long relationship with the firm
questions.explanation: High-risk third-party wires without a clear purpose are a red flag; escalation and due diligence are required.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the role of sanctions screening (e.g., OFAC) in AML programs?
options: It is unrelated to AML and can be ignored
It helps ensure the firm does not transact with sanctioned persons/entities and supports broader financial crime controls
It applies only to cash transactions
It is only required for international firms
questions.explanation: Sanctions controls are a core financial crime control and are commonly integrated with AML compliance programs.

questions.question: Scenario: A colleague suggests sharing SAR-related details with a client to 'clear things up.' What should you do?
options: Agree; transparency always helps
Decline and remind them SAR-related information is confidential; follow firm procedures
Post the SAR on social media
Email the client the internal suspicion notes
questions.explanation: SAR confidentiality is critical; tipping off can create legal and regulatory risk.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to be considered an AML red flag requiring further review?
options: A client updates their mailing address after moving
A client refuses to provide beneficial ownership information for a legal entity and uses complex structures without a clear business purpose
A client requests electronic statements
A client asks about fee schedules
questions.explanation: Opaque ownership structures and refusal to provide ownership information can indicate elevated financial crime risk and require escalation.

questions.question: What is the best description of 'risk-based' AML controls?
options: Applying identical procedures to all clients regardless of risk
Applying enhanced controls where risk is higher and simplified controls where risk is lower, consistent with policy and law
Disabling monitoring for top clients
Only monitoring transactions over a fixed dollar amount
questions.explanation: Risk-based programs allocate controls proportionate to identified risk, using enhanced due diligence where warranted.

questions.question: Scenario: You see repeated rapid movement of funds in and out of an account with little apparent economic purpose. What is the best response?
options: Ignore it; rapid movement is normal
Escalate per AML procedures and document observations (dates, amounts, pattern) for review
Advise the client to use cash instead
Recommend higher-risk products to match the activity
questions.explanation: Pattern-based concerns should be escalated with clear documentation to support investigation and potential reporting.

title: NASAA IAR CE: Ethics for Investment Advisers
description: Applies investment adviser fiduciary principles, conflict management, Form ADV disclosure expectations, and practical ethics scenarios relevant to NASAA IAR CE.

questions.question: Under the NASAA IAR CE model, what is the annual CE requirement (in jurisdictions that have adopted the model rule)?
options: 6 credits total
12 credits total: 6 Ethics & Professional Responsibility and 6 Products & Practice
20 credits total
30 credits total
questions.explanation: NASAA's IAR CE model requires 12 credits annually, split between Ethics & Professional Responsibility and Products & Practice.

questions.question: Which statement best describes an investment adviser's fiduciary duty (general SEC/NASAA concept)?
options: Only a duty to follow client instructions, regardless of conflicts
A duty of care and a duty of loyalty, including putting the client's interests first and managing conflicts
A duty to guarantee returns
A duty limited only to execution of trades
questions.explanation: Fiduciary duty generally includes care (competent advice and monitoring) and loyalty (full and fair disclosure and conflict management).

questions.question: Scenario: You receive compensation from a third party for recommending a product platform, and the client is not aware. What is the most appropriate action?
options: Do nothing if performance is good
Provide full and fair disclosure of the conflict (including compensation) before or at the time of the recommendation and obtain informed consent as required
Disclose only if asked
Disclose only to your supervisor
questions.explanation: Third-party compensation is a conflict requiring full and fair disclosure in a manner clients can understand, before advice is acted upon.

questions.question: Which document is primarily used to disclose an adviser's services, fees, conflicts, and disciplinary information to clients (U.S. context)?
options: Form W-2
Form ADV (especially Part 2A/2B as applicable)
IRS Form 1040
Form 1099-DIV
questions.explanation: Form ADV (notably the brochure and brochure supplement) is a key disclosure document for advisory clients.

questions.question: Scenario: An adviser is trading a security in their personal account shortly before placing the same order for clients, benefiting from the price movement. This conduct is best described as:
options: Diversification
Front-running (a serious conflict/breach)
Tax-loss harvesting
Rebalancing
questions.explanation: Trading ahead of clients to benefit personally is a severe conflict and can violate fiduciary and compliance obligations.

questions.question: Which statement about conflicts of interest is most accurate?
options: Disclosure alone always eliminates a conflict
Conflicts must be identified and either eliminated or mitigated/manageable with clear disclosure; some conflicts may be so severe they must be avoided
Conflicts only exist in commission accounts
Conflicts do not apply to advisory firms
questions.explanation: Disclosure is necessary but not always sufficient; firms must assess whether conflicts can be effectively managed.

questions.question: Scenario: A client's portfolio is concentrated in a single stock due to legacy holdings, creating high idiosyncratic risk. What is the most appropriate advice approach?
options: Ignore concentration because the client chose it
Explain concentration risk, explore constraints (tax/lockups), propose a risk-managed transition plan, and document suitability rationale
Recommend doubling the position
Recommend only day trading to diversify
questions.explanation: A prudent fiduciary approach explains risks, considers constraints, proposes a plan consistent with objectives, and documents the rationale.

questions.question: Which control is most closely associated with a registered investment adviser's written compliance framework?
options: A social media influencer agreement
Policies and procedures designed to prevent violations, including periodic review
A marketing slogan
A client waiver of complaints
questions.explanation: Advisers are expected to maintain and review compliance policies and procedures to prevent violations of the Advisers Act and related rules.

questions.question: Scenario: A client asks you to omit a liability from their net worth statement to qualify for a product. What is the best response?
options: Agree to improve their approval odds
Refuse, explain the importance of accurate information, and document the interaction; escalate if needed
Proceed but keep it verbal
Suggest they sign a statement that makes you not responsible
questions.explanation: Providing or facilitating misleading information is unethical and risky; accuracy and documentation are essential.

questions.question: Which statement best captures the goal of 'full and fair disclosure' of conflicts?
options: Use technical language so clients won't ask questions
Provide clear, specific information in plain language so the client can understand the conflict and its potential impact
Disclose only once at account opening regardless of changes
Disclose only to regulators, not clients
questions.explanation: Full and fair disclosure must be understandable and specific enough for a client to evaluate the conflict.

title: FCA Consumer Duty and Treating Customers Fairly (Retail Advice)
description: Consumer Duty fundamentals for retail advisers: consumer principle, cross-cutting rules, outcomes, vulnerable customers, and practical advice-process implications.

questions.question: The FCA's Consumer Duty is best described as:
options: A one-time disclosure form for new clients
A standard requiring firms to act to deliver good outcomes for retail customers, supported by cross-cutting rules and outcomes
A tax reporting framework
A rule that only applies to wholesale clients
questions.explanation: The Consumer Duty is an outcomes-focused standard for retail customers, supported by cross-cutting rules and four outcomes.

questions.question: Which option correctly lists the Consumer Duty's cross-cutting rules (high-level)?
options: Act quickly, maximise profit, and minimise documentation
Act in good faith, avoid causing foreseeable harm, and enable and support customers to pursue their financial objectives
Sell only regulated products, avoid all complaints, and outsource all decisions
Provide no advice, only execution-only service
questions.explanation: The cross-cutting rules require good faith, avoiding foreseeable harm, and enabling/supporting customers to pursue their objectives.

questions.question: Which set correctly reflects the Consumer Duty's four outcomes?
options: Disclosure, marketing, tax, and HR
Products and services; price and value; consumer understanding; consumer support
Trading, custody, settlement, and reporting
Capital, liquidity, leverage, and stress testing
questions.explanation: The Duty's outcomes cover products/services, price/value, consumer understanding, and consumer support.

questions.question: Scenario: A firm provides a complex suitability report full of jargon that a typical retail client is unlikely to understand. Which Consumer Duty outcome is most directly implicated?
options: Price and value
Consumer understanding
Products and services
Capital adequacy
questions.explanation: Consumer understanding requires communications that equip customers to make informed decisions, not just technically accurate documents.

questions.question: Scenario: A client has low financial literacy and is experiencing health issues that affect decision-making. What is the most appropriate adviser approach?
options: Proceed at normal speed because deadlines matter more
Identify vulnerability, adapt communications and support, and document steps taken to enable informed decisions
Refuse service without explanation
Only communicate by email using technical terms
questions.explanation: FCA expectations on vulnerable customers emphasize tailored support and communications to avoid foreseeable harm.

questions.question: Which statement best reflects how Treating Customers Fairly (TCF) relates to the Consumer Duty?
options: TCF is abolished and irrelevant
The Duty builds on and strengthens the FCA's focus on customer outcomes; firms should not treat it as a box-tick add-on
TCF applies only to mortgages; the Duty applies only to pensions
They conflict and cannot be applied together
questions.explanation: The Duty is an outcomes-focused framework that reinforces and raises expectations around customer outcomes.

questions.question: Which is a core element of suitability in UK retail investment advice?
options: Recommending the product with the highest commission
Basing personal recommendations on a client's objectives, financial situation, and knowledge/experience
Using the same recommendation for all clients
Avoiding any risk discussion
questions.explanation: Suitability requires aligning advice to the client's circumstances and objectives, including appropriate assessment and rationale.

questions.question: Scenario: An adviser is incentivised by a provider to recommend a product. What is the most appropriate Consumer Duty-aligned action?
options: Recommend it to meet quarterly targets
Identify and manage the conflict, ensure advice is in the client's best interests/outcomes, and document the rationale and alternatives considered
Do not disclose the incentive to avoid confusion
Only recommend it to vulnerable customers
questions.explanation: Incentives can create conflicts and foreseeable harm. Advisers should manage conflicts, consider alternatives, and document outcomes-based reasoning.

questions.question: Which operational practice most helps demonstrate Consumer Duty compliance over time?
options: Relying only on verbal attestations
Maintaining clear MI and evidence of outcomes (e.g., suitability rationale, communications testing, complaint learnings)
Deleting historical records to reduce storage cost
Avoiding any client feedback collection
questions.explanation: The Duty is outcomes-based; monitoring and evidence (MI, testing, learnings) help demonstrate compliance.

questions.question: Scenario: A product appears reasonably suitable but is priced such that the client receives poor value relative to benefits and alternatives. Which outcome is most directly implicated?
options: Consumer support
Price and value
Products and services
Consumer understanding
questions.explanation: Price and value focuses on whether total price is reasonable relative to benefits and the target market.

title: ASIC CPD + Adviser Professionalism and Ethics (Australia)
description: Australia financial adviser CPD obligations and ethics: CPD Determination categories, recordkeeping, best interests duty, conflicts, and practical professionalism scenarios.

questions.question: Under ASIC's CPD guidance for relevant providers, what is the minimum annual CPD requirement (full-time) and key mandatory categories?
options: 10 hours; marketing and sales only
40 hours; including minimum hours across technical competence, client care and practice, regulatory compliance and consumer protection, and professionalism and ethics
25 hours; any category
40 hours; only technical competence
questions.explanation: ASIC explains relevant providers must complete at least 40 hours annually with minimum hours across mandatory categories including professionalism/ethics and regulatory compliance.

questions.question: Scenario: You have a sales target that encourages recommending a higher-margin product even when a lower-cost alternative better fits the client. What is the most appropriate action?
options: Proceed to meet the target
Prioritise the client's interests, manage/avoid the conflict, document alternatives considered, and recommend the option that best meets the client's needs
Recommend the high-margin product but do not disclose incentives
Only disclose after the client signs
questions.explanation: Professionalism and client-first obligations require prioritising client interests and managing conflicts; documentation supports defensibility.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the 'best interests duty' in Australian personal advice (general concept)?
options: A duty to maximise adviser revenue
A duty to act in the best interests of the client when providing personal advice and to satisfy related obligations (including prioritising client interests)
A duty only to provide product disclosure statements
A duty that applies only to wholesale clients
questions.explanation: Australian personal advice includes a best interests duty and related priority obligations to put client interests first.

questions.question: Scenario: A client's objectives are unclear and they provide incomplete information. What is the most appropriate advice process step?
options: Make assumptions and proceed
Clarify objectives, gather relevant information, explain why it is needed, and document limitations if information remains incomplete
Recommend the same product used for other clients
Avoid documenting gaps to reduce work
questions.explanation: A defensible advice process requires understanding objectives and collecting sufficient information; documenting limitations is critical if constraints remain.

questions.question: According to ASIC, who approves CPD activities that count toward the annual CPD requirement?
options: Only ASIC approves all CPD activities
The adviser's authorising AFS licensee (at least 70% of minimum hours must be approved by the licensee)
Any social media influencer
No approval is required for any activity
questions.explanation: ASIC explains the Minister does not approve activities; licensees approve qualifying activities and must ensure minimum percentages are licensee-approved.

questions.question: Scenario: You are authorised to provide tax (financial) advice services to retail clients. What additional CPD requirement may apply under ASIC guidance?
options: No change; tax advice never affects CPD
An additional minimum number of CPD hours in the area of tax (financial) advice
Only more hours in marketing
A requirement to complete U.S. IRS training
questions.explanation: ASIC notes an additional minimum CPD requirement can apply for relevant providers authorised to provide tax (financial) advice services.

questions.question: Which recordkeeping expectation is explicitly emphasized in ASIC CPD guidance?
options: CPD records are optional if you remember what you did
Relevant providers (or licensees) must keep complete and accurate records of CPD activity and provide them on request
Only webinar attendance must be kept; nothing else
Records should be destroyed immediately after renewal
questions.explanation: ASIC highlights complete and accurate CPD records are required and must be available to the licensee on request.

questions.question: Scenario: You discover you are behind on CPD hours near the end of the CPD year. Which action best reflects good practice and compliance?
options: Ignore it; CPD is not enforced
Escalate to your licensee/compliance function, create a remediation plan, and avoid leaving CPD to the last minute in future
Backdate CPD entries to fill gaps
Ask a colleague to complete CPD on your behalf
questions.explanation: ASIC has acted on CPD non-compliance; remediation should be transparent and documented, never falsified.

questions.question: Which CPD category has the highest minimum hours requirement under the CPD Determination (as commonly summarised by ASIC)?
options: Technical competence
Client care and practice
Regulatory compliance and consumer protection
Professionalism and ethics
questions.explanation: ASIC summarises minimum hours across mandatory categories, with professionalism and ethics typically having the largest minimum allocation.

questions.question: Scenario: A colleague suggests recording mandatory fire training as CPD to reach the 40-hour total. What is the best response?
options: Agree; any training counts
Decline and include only qualifying CPD relevant to professional capabilities; document the rationale and seek compliance guidance if unsure
Include it but rename it 'ethics'
Delete records to avoid review
questions.explanation: CPD must be relevant to maintaining and extending professional capabilities; misclassifying training undermines audit readiness and integrity.

title: FP Canada CFP Professional Responsibility and Standards of Conduct
description: Professional responsibility CE aligned to FP Canada standards: ethical dilemmas, conflicts, client-first conduct, documentation, and CE compliance practices.

questions.question: According to FP Canada CE requirements, CFP professionals must complete how many CE credits per calendar year?
questions.explanation: FP Canada states CFP professionals are required to complete 25 hours of CE annually (calendar year basis).

questions.question: What is the minimum Professional Responsibility (PR) CE requirement for FP Canada CFP professionals per calendar year?
questions.explanation: FP Canada's CE requirements include a minimum number of PR credits per year for CFP professionals.

questions.question: Scenario: You receive a referral fee for sending clients to an insurance agent. What is the most appropriate professional responsibility action?
options: Do not disclose; it's standard practice
Disclose the referral arrangement and any conflicts clearly to the client and document consent
Disclose only if the client complains
Ask the agent to pay the fee to a family member instead
questions.explanation: Referral compensation creates a conflict; professional responsibility standards require transparent disclosure and appropriate conflict management.

questions.question: Which statement best reflects FP Canada's approach to Professional Responsibility CE content (high-level)?
options: Any financial topic automatically counts as PR
PR CE focuses on applying professional responsibility standards through examples, case studies, and assessments relevant to practice
PR CE is only about investment performance
PR CE is optional for CFP professionals
questions.explanation: FP Canada describes PR CE as applied, case-based learning aligned to its Standards of Professional Responsibility.

questions.question: Scenario: A client asks you to 'round down' debt amounts on a financial plan to improve loan eligibility. What should you do?
options: Agree; it helps the client
Refuse, explain the need for accurate information, and document the interaction
Comply but keep it verbal
Send the client a template to fill in anything they want
questions.explanation: Integrity and client-first standards require accuracy; facilitating misleading information is unethical and risky.

questions.question: Which is a best practice for managing a potential conflict between adviser compensation and client outcomes?
options: Avoid documenting compensation details
Identify the conflict, disclose it plainly, mitigate where possible, and recommend based on the client's goals and best interests
Recommend whichever product pays more
Let the client discover costs after implementation
questions.explanation: Professional responsibility requires conflict identification, clear disclosure, and mitigation to keep advice aligned with client interests.

questions.question: Scenario: A client's situation involves complex tax issues outside your competence. What is the best professional response?
options: Provide definitive tax advice anyway
Explain limitations, recommend consulting a qualified tax professional, and coordinate as appropriate
Tell the client taxes are irrelevant
Copy advice from a forum
questions.explanation: Professional responsibility includes recognizing limits of competence and referring to appropriate experts when needed.

questions.question: Effective January 2025, FP Canada added a 'Professional Skills' sub-category under which CE category for CFP professionals?
options: Professional Responsibility
Financial Planning
General CE only
Giving Back only
questions.explanation: FP Canada states Professional Skills was added as a sub-category under Financial Planning effective January 2025.

questions.question: What does FP Canada advise regarding evidence of CE completion (audit readiness)?
options: You must submit all proof with renewal every year
You do not need to submit proof on renewal, but you should keep documentation for a period in case you are audited
Proof is never required
Only verbal confirmation is needed
questions.explanation: FP Canada advises keeping proof of completed CE for a period (e.g., three years) in case of audit, even if not submitted at renewal.

questions.question: Scenario: A client complains that they did not understand key fees disclosed in documents. Which practice most directly helps prevent this?
options: Rely solely on lengthy disclosures
Use plain-language explanations, confirm understanding, and document the conversation
Avoid discussing fees to keep meetings short
Only disclose fees after the first year
questions.explanation: Plain-language discussion and confirmation of understanding supports informed consent and reduces foreseeable misunderstandings.
